title: 103_hr764
content: The "Windstorm Hazard Reduction Plan Act of 1993" was enacted due to the significant losses suffered by the property and casualty insurance industry in 1992 from natural disasters, particularly windstorms like hurricanes and tornadoes. This Act addresses the withdrawal of underwriting capacity by insurers in certain regions of the United States and territories, leading to unaffordable premiums or refusal to issue new policies. The "Windstorm Hazard Reduction Plan Act of 1993" requires the Director of FEMA to develop a national windstorm insurance program within 90 days. The plan aims to provide affordable insurance coverage for residential structures against wind damage from hurricanes, tornadoes, and other windstorms. The Windstorm Hazard Reduction Plan Act of 1993 aims to provide affordable insurance coverage for residential structures against wind damage from hurricanes, tornadoes, and other windstorms. The program includes insurance coverage for wind damage, building requirements, mitigation measures, incentives for insurers, and potential coverage for public infrastructure. The national windstorm insurance program may cover public infrastructure facilities, residential, business, agricultural properties, and properties owned by private nonprofit organizations. It may involve private insurance industry participation, coinsurance, reinsurance, and defined coverage areas. The national windstorm insurance program covers various types of properties and infrastructure, with participation from private insurers. It defines coverage areas, types of properties eligible, and establishes premium rates based on risk. It also adjusts the availability of federal assistance for disaster relief. The Director shall consult with Federal agencies, state executives, and private insurers for the national windstorm insurance program. SEC. 4. REPORT. The Director must submit a report to specific committees within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The report should include a written plan, details on disaster assistance provided for property damage caused by windstorms in fiscal years 1989-1992, and an estimate of the cost of the national windstorm insurance program. The Director must submit a report within 90 days of the Act's enactment, including a plan for the national windstorm insurance program. The report should estimate the cost of the program and detail circumstances for coverage of public infrastructure and properties owned by State and local governments, residential, business, agricultural properties, and private nonprofit organizations. The report on the national windstorm insurance program must include estimates on the impact on disaster assistance, private insurance industry, necessary amendments to related Acts, and any other relevant information as deemed appropriate by the Director.
